content.text: From Fig. 1.2, take and record measurements to determine an accurate value for the diameter \(D_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the base of the cup
The student places the cup upside down and draws around the rim of the cup
She determines the diameter \(D_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the rim of the cup
Calculate the average diameter \(D\) of the cup using the equation \(D = \frac{D_{\mathrm{B}} + D_{\mathrm{T}}}{2}\)
She draws around the base of the cup. Her drawing is shown in Fig. 1.2
1. On Fig. 1.3, measure the vertical height \(h\) of the cup
Fig. 1.3
2. Calculate the volume \(V\) of the cup using the equation \(V = 0.785 D^2 h\)
The student fills the cup with water. The mass of the cup with the water is shown in Fig. 1.4
Fig. 1.4
Determine the density \(\rho\) of water using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m}{V}\) and your value from **(b)2**
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment. Include the unit
Suggest, with a reason, a part of the procedure **(a)**, **(b)** or **(c)** that could give an unreliable result for the density of water
part
reason
The student pours the water from the cup into a measuring cylinder
Draw a diagram to show water in a measuring cylinder. Show clearly the meniscus and the line of sight the student should use to obtain an accurate value for the volume of the water
A student is determining the density of water. She is provided with a plastic cup, shown in Fig. 1.1
The thermometer in Fig. 2.2 shows room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Explain why the student should wait a few seconds after placing the thermometer in the hot water before taking the first temperature reading
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
Complete the time column in Table 2.1

Plot a graph of \(\theta /\mathrm{^\circ C}\) (y-axis) against \(t / \mathrm{s}\) (x-axis). You do **not** need to start the \(y\)-axis at the origin (0,0) but the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) must be marked on the \(y\)-axis
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
He records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately starts a stopclock
He continues recording the temperature readings every 30s. The readings are shown in Table 2.1
Draw a horizontal line across the graph grid to indicate the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\), as shown by the thermometer in Fig. 2.2
State two precautions that you would take in order to obtain accurate readings in this experiment
A student plans to repeat the experiment using the same thermometer and the same volume of water
Suggest two changes to the apparatus or the procedure that would **increase** the rate of cooling of the water
A student is investigating the cooling of water
Fig. 2.1 shows the apparatus used
On Fig. 3.1, measure the distance \(\nu\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Fig. 3.1 is drawn \(1 / 5^{\text{th}}\) actual size
Calculate \(V,\) the actual distance from the lens to the screen
With a clearly focused image formed on the screen, the actual distance from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object, \(U\) is \(20.0 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the focal length \(f_{1}\) of the lens using the equation \(f_{1} = \frac{UV}{(U + V)}\)
The student adjusts the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
The student repeats the procedure in **(a)**, using a different distance \(U\). She obtains another value for the focal length \(f_2\)

Calculate the average value \(f_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the focal length of the lens, using \(f_{2}\) and your value for \(f_{1}\) in **(a)**(iii). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
The student states that taking more measurements improves the reliability of the value obtained for \(f_{\mathrm{A}}\)
Suggest additional values for \(U\) that you would use
State two precautions that you would take in this experiment to obtain accurate readings
A student is determining the focal length of a lens
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus used
Fig. 3.1
A student is investigating whether the distance that a toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass
The following apparatus is available to the student:
a ramp
blocks to support the ramp as shown in Fig. 4.1
toy truck
a selection of masses
other standard apparatus from the physics laboratory
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the distance that the toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass
In your plan, you should:
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation
state any apparatus that you would use that is not included in the list above
state the key variables that you would control
draw a table, or tables, with column headings to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
You may add to the diagram in Fig. 4.1 to help your description
